class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div id=\"MicrositeSearch\" class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                                    <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Issue\" >This issue</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"\" selected=&quot;selected&quot;>All  Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</option>\r\n\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                                    <optgroup label=\"Search beyond this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Parent\" >All  RAS Journals</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Journals\" >All  Journals</option>\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                            </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=129897273 id=\"129897273\" class=\"abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Strong-gravitational lens systems with quadruply imaged quasars (quads) are unique probes to address several fundamental problems in cosmology and astrophysics. Although they are intrinsically very rare, ongoing and planned wide-field deep-sky surveys are set to discover thousands of such systems in the next decade. It is thus paramount to devise a general framework to model strong-lens systems to cope with this large influx without being limited by expert investigator time. We propose such a general modelling framework (implemented with the publicly available software <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstronomy</span>) and apply it to uniformly model three-band <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> Wide Field Camera 3 images of 13 quads. This is the largest uniformly modelled sample of quads to date and paves the way for a variety of studies. To illustrate the scientific content of the sample, we investigate the alignment between the mass and light distribution in the deflectors. The position angles of these distributions are well-aligned, except when there is strong external shear. However, we find no correlation between the ellipticity of the light and mass distributions. We also show that the observed flux-ratios between the images depart significantly from the predictions of simple smooth models. The departures are strongest in the bluest band, consistent with microlensing being the dominant cause in addition to millilensing. Future papers will exploit this rich data set in combination with ground-based spectroscopy and time delays to determine quantities such as the Hubble constant, the free streaming length of dark matter, and the normalization of the initial stellar mass function.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;methods: data analysis&quot;\">methods: data analysis</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: elliptical and lenticular, cD&quot;\">galaxies: elliptical and lenticular, cD</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: structure&quot;\">galaxies: structure</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=129897275 id=\"129897275\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Strong gravitational lensing is the effect where light from a background object is deflected by a foreground mass distribution (e.g. galaxy or galaxy cluster) and multiple images of the background object form. Strong gravitational lenses are powerful probes to answer a variety of astrophysical and cosmological questions (see e.g. Treu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib125\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib125\" data-open=\"bib125\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), as we discuss briefly below.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">According to the concordance model in cosmology, our Universe consists of 5 per cent baryonic matter, 26 per cent dark matter, and 69 per cent dark energy accounting for a cosmological constant \u039b (Planck Collaboration VI <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). This model is known as the \u039b cold dark matter (\u039bCDM) model. The predictions of the \u039bCDM model have been extensively tested with good agreement to observations spanning from the largest scale up to the horizon down to \u223c1 Mpc (e.g. Dawson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Shajib &amp; Wright <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Planck Collaboration VI <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). However, there also have been observations that are in tension with the flat \u039bCDM paradigm. For instance, there is a tension at the \u22733\u03c3 level between the local measurement of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> from Type Ia supernovae (Bernal, Verde &amp; Riess <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Riess et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>) and that extrapolated from the <em>Planck</em> cosmic microwave background measurement for a flat \u039bCDM cosmology. This tension may arise from unknown systematic uncertainties in one or both of the measurements, or might point to new physics, e.g. additional species of relativistic particles, a non-flat cosmology, or dynamic dark energy. Therefore, it is crucial to have precise and independent measurements of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> to settle this discrepancy.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In a gravitational lens, if the background source is time-variable (typically a quasar, but also a supernova as originally proposed), the delay between the arrival time of photons for the different images can be used to measure the so-called time-delay distance (Refsdal <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1964</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib122\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib122\" data-open=\"bib122\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). This distance is inversely proportional to <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>, thus it can be used to constrain <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> and other cosmological parameters (for a detailed review, see Treu &amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib126\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib126\" data-open=\"bib126\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> has been determined to 3.8 per cent precision using three lens systems in the flat \u039bCDM cosmology (Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib122\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib122\" data-open=\"bib122\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib120\" data-open=\"bib120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib121\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib121\" data-open=\"bib121\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Bonvin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Rusu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Sluse et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib115\" data-open=\"bib115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Wong et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib141\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib141\" data-open=\"bib141\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Tihhonova et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib123\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib123\" data-open=\"bib123\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). With a large sample size of about 40 lenses, it is possible to measure <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> with the per cent precision (Jee et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Shajib, Treu &amp; Agnello <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib114\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib114\" data-open=\"bib114\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) necessary to resolve the <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> tension and make the most of other dark energy probes (Linder <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib119\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib119\" data-open=\"bib119\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Weinberg et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib137\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib137\" data-open=\"bib137\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">One of the baryonic components in dark matter is low-mass star. Surprisingly, recent studies have shown that the low-mass star contribution in massive elliptical galaxies is significantly underestimated if the stellar initial mass function (IMF) of the Milky Way is assumed (Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib128\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib128\" data-open=\"bib128\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; van Dokkum &amp; Conroy <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib129\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib129\" data-open=\"bib129\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Auger et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>; Cappellari et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib108\" data-open=\"bib108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Precise knowledge about the IMF is key in measuring almost any extragalactic quantity involving star and metal formation. Measuring the stellar mass-to-light ratio in the deflectors of quadruply imaged lensed quasars (henceforth quads) from microlensing statistics provides one of the most robust methods to constrain the IMF (e.g. Oguri, Rusu &amp; Falco <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib108\" data-open=\"bib108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Quads also provide a unique test of small-scale structure formation (Kauffmann, White &amp; Guiderdoni <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>; Witt, Mao &amp; Schechter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib140\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib140\" data-open=\"bib140\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>; Klypin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Moore et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Metcalf &amp; Madau <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>; Dalal &amp; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Yoo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Keeton &amp; Moustakas <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Moustakas et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Boylan-Kolchin, Bullock &amp; Kaplinghat <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) by measuring the subhalo mass function (Metcalf &amp; Zhao <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Kochanek &amp; Dalal <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Amara et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Metcalf &amp; Amara <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Nierenberg et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Xu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib142\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib142\" data-open=\"bib142\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Birrer, Amara &amp; Refregier <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>, see also for studies involving extended source only, Koopmans <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Vegetti &amp; Koopmans <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib130\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib130\" data-open=\"bib130\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Vegetti et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib131\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib131\" data-open=\"bib131\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib132\" data-open=\"bib132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib133\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib133\" data-open=\"bib133\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Hezaveh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), independent of their luminosity function. With a large sample of quads, Gilman et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) demonstrate the possibility of constraining the free-streaming length of dark matter particles more precisely than current limits based on the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 forest (Viel et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib134\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib134\" data-open=\"bib134\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Until recently, all of these methods could only be applied to a small sample of known quads. However, such systems are currently being discovered at a rapidly increasing rate due to multiple strong-lens search efforts involving various large-area sky surveys (e.g. Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">c</a>; Williams, Agnello &amp; Treu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib138\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib138\" data-open=\"bib138\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib109\" data-open=\"bib109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Anguita et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Sonnenfeld et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib117\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib117\" data-open=\"bib117\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib124\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib124\" data-open=\"bib124\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Williams et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib139\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib139\" data-open=\"bib139\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). With more deep wide-field surveys, e.g. <em>Wide-Field Infrared Survey Telescope</em>, Large Synoptic Survey Telescope, and <em>Euclid</em>, coming online within the next decade, the sample size of quads is expected to increase by two orders of magnitude or more (Oguri &amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Collett <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Modelling such lens systems has so far been carried out for individual systems while fine-tuning the modelling approach on a case-by-case basis. However, with the rapidly increasing rate of discovery, it is essential to develop a modelling technique that is applicable to a wide variety of quads to efficiently reduce the time and human labour necessary in this endeavour. Given the large diversity in the morphology and complexity of quads, this is an interesting problem to pose: is every quad different or \u2018unhappy in its own way\u2019 that requires careful decision-making by a human in the modelling procedure, or are the quads similar or \u2018happy\u2019 to some extent so that a uniform modelling technique can be applied to generate acceptable models without much human intervention?</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Recently, some initial strides have been undertaken along the lines of solving this problem for strong lenses with extended sources. Nightingale, Dye &amp; Massey (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) devised an automated lens modelling procedure using Bayesian model comparison. Hezaveh, Levasseur &amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and Perreault Levasseur, Hezaveh &amp; Wechsler (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib97\" data-open=\"bib97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) applied machine learning techniques to automatically model strong gravitational lenses and constrain the model parameters. In this paper, we devise a general framework or decision tree that can be applied to model-fitting of quads both in a single band and simultaneously in multiple bands. We implement this uniform modelling approach using the publicly available lens-modelling software <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstronomy</span> (Birrer &amp; Amara <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>, based on Birrer, Amara &amp; Refregier <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) to a sample of 13 quads from the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) data in three bands. <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstronomy</span> comes with sufficient modelling tools and the architecture allows a build-up in complexity as presented in this work. We report the model parameters and other derived quantities for these lens systems.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To demonstrate the scientific capabilities of such a sample of strong-lens systems, we study the properties of the deflector galaxy mass distribution, specifically the alignment of the mass and light distributions in them. The distribution of dark matter and baryons in galaxies can test predictions of \u039bCDM and galaxy formation theories (e.g. Dubinski <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1994</a>; Ibata et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>; Kazantzidis et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Macci\u00f2 et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Debattista et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Lux et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Read <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib99\" data-open=\"bib99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). <em>N</em>-body simulations with only dark matter particles predict nearly triaxial, prolate haloes (Dubinski &amp; Carlberg <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1991</a>; Warren et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib135\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib135\" data-open=\"bib135\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>; Navarro, Frenk &amp; White <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Jing &amp; Suto <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Macci\u00f2 et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). In the presence of baryons, the haloes become rounder (Dubinski &amp; Carlberg <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1991</a>; Warren et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib135\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib135\" data-open=\"bib135\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>; Dubinski <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1994</a>). With a modestly triaxial luminous galaxy embedded in the dark matter halo, large misalignments (\u223c16\u00a0\u00b1\u00a019\u00b0) between the projected light and mass major axes can be produced (Romanowsky &amp; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>). For disc galaxies, the dark matter distribution is shown to be well-aligned with the light distribution (Dubinski &amp; Carlberg <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1991</a>; Katz &amp; Gunn <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1991</a>; Debattista et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As the lensing effect is generated by mass, strong gravitational lenses give independent estimates of the mass distribution that can be compared with the observed light distribution. The deflectors in quads are typically massive ellipticals (with Einstein mass <em>M</em><sub>E</sub> \u2273 10<sup>11.5</sup>M<sub>\u2299</sub>). Most of the massive ellipticals are observed to be slow rotators with uniformly distributed misalignments between the kinematic and photometric axes (Ene et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). The uniform distribution of misalignments suggests these massive ellipticals to be intrinsically triaxial. Massive ellipticals can also have of stellar populations and dust distribution with different geometries producing isophotal twist that can create a misalignment between the mass and light distributions (Goullaud et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). For lens systems, a tight alignment within \u00b110\u00b0 between the major axes of the mass and light distribution has been observed for deflector galaxies with weak external shear, whereas galaxies with strong external shear can be highly misaligned (Keeton, Kochanek &amp; Falco <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib127\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib127\" data-open=\"bib127\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Sluse et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib116\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib116\" data-open=\"bib116\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Bruderer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). However, there has been some conflict about the correlation between the ellipticity of the mass and light distributions with reports of both strong correlation (Sluse et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib116\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib116\" data-open=\"bib116\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) and no correlation (Keeton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Ferreras, Saha &amp; Burles <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Rusu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib106\" data-open=\"bib106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper is organized as follows. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, we describe the data used in this study. We describe our methodology in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.3</a> and the results in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>. Finally, we summarize the paper followed by a discussion in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>. When necessary, we adopt a fiducial cosmology with <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 70\u2009km s<sup>\u22121</sup> Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>, \u03a9<sub>m</sub> = 0.3, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> = 0.7, and \u03a9<sub>r</sub> = 0. All magnitudes are given in the AB system.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=129897287 id=\"129897287\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 <em>HST</em> SAMPLE</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our sample consists of 12 quads and one five-image system. Some of these systems were discovered by the STRong-lensing Insights into the Dark Energy Survey (STRIDES)<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> collaboration [STRIDES paper I Treu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib124\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib124\" data-open=\"bib124\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), paper II Anguita et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), and paper III Ostrovski et\u00a0al. (in preparation)], some are recent discoveries by independent searches outside of the Dark Energy Survey (DES), and some are selected from the literature. In this section, we first describe the high-resolution imaging data obtained through <em>HST</em>. We then briefly describe the lens systems in the sample.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=129897289 id=\"129897289\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 Data</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Images of the lenses were obtained using the <em>HST</em> Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) in three filters: F160W in the infrared (IR) channel, and F814W and F475X in the ultraviolet-visual (UVIS) channel (ID 15320, PI Treu). In the IR channel filter, we used a four-point dither pattern and <span class=\"small-caps\">STEP100</span> readout sequence for the <span class=\"small-caps\">multiaccum</span> mode. This approach guarantees a sufficient dynamic range to expose both the bright lensed quasar images and the extended host galaxy. For the UVIS channel filters, we used a two-point dither pattern. Two exposures at each position, one short and one long, were taken. Total exposure times for all the quads and the corresponding dates of observation are tabulated in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. The data were reduced using <span class=\"small-caps\">astrodrizzle</span>. The pixel size after drizzling is 0.08\u00a0arcsec in the F160W band, and 0.04\u00a0arcsec in the F814W and F475X bands.</p>                        <a id=\"129897291\" scrollto-destination=\"129897291\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>PS J1606\u20132333\u00a0</td><td>2017 Sept 1\u00a0</td><td>2196.9\u00a0</td><td>1428.0\u00a0</td><td>994.0\u00a0</td><td>Lemon et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1330+1810\u00a0</td><td>2018 Aug 15\u00a0</td><td>2196.9\u00a0</td><td>1428.0\u00a0</td><td>994.0\u00a0</td><td>Oguri et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1433+6007\u00a0</td><td>2018 May 4\u00a0</td><td>2196.9\u00a0</td><td>1428.0\u00a0</td><td>1504.0\u00a0</td><td>Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>PS J1606\u20132333\u00a0</td><td>2017 Sept 1\u00a0</td><td>2196.9\u00a0</td><td>1428.0\u00a0</td><td>994.0\u00a0</td><td>Lemon et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DES J2038\u20134008\u00a0</td><td>2017 Aug 29\u00a0</td><td>2196.9\u00a0</td><td>1428.0\u00a0</td><td>1158.0\u00a0</td><td>Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018c</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WISE J2344\u20133056\u00a0</td><td>2017 Sept 9\u00a0</td><td>2196.9\u00a0</td><td>1428.0\u00a0</td><td>1042.0\u00a0</td><td>Schechter et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib109\" data-open=\"bib109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>)\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/129897291\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=129897292 id=\"129897292\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 Quads in the sample</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this subsection, we give a brief description of each quad in our sample (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"129897294\" scrollto-destination=\"129897294\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/4/10.1093_mnras_sty3397/2/m_sty3397fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465403&amp;Signature=aq-kp9xWrPfEY-cwO88eWxY70aFaWxSBQJ8r~ShUV-ogWn04AsVC65Y-KtbjrZPf15FJFXrHLlVaf5JlxzcSoowJBR3NnFCqpquCTD1JEfa6bg1SGPuOo7kbyDaRuBPcfe9rLq41M~7ud07AzVCoxydxZY8blDshowsIQiQM5IqMz45uAcjJZm-99wfeJlPMNL49ZHgeA5o~rIoNt18ns0A01Qosd1pRjA38qPJXQudukNRcKTpnIk3J-bi26xa2c0vCZHOKNymlf61-mOSMP7Z3yZmZhTDTeNR1ATSrDmW60oT~wYtETjVPUMI2hi6mRxcywtgTZrbWcejzPzQM~Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison between the observed (first, third, and fifth columns) and reconstructed (second, fourth, and sixth columns) strong-lens systems. Horizontal white lines for each system are rulers showing 1 arcsec. Horizontal white lines for each system are rulers showing 1 arcsec. The relative intensities of the bands have been adjusted for each lens system for clear visualization of the features in the system.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/4/10.1093_mnras_sty3397/2/m_sty3397fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465403&amp;Signature=aq-kp9xWrPfEY-cwO88eWxY70aFaWxSBQJ8r~ShUV-ogWn04AsVC65Y-KtbjrZPf15FJFXrHLlVaf5JlxzcSoowJBR3NnFCqpquCTD1JEfa6bg1SGPuOo7kbyDaRuBPcfe9rLq41M~7ud07AzVCoxydxZY8blDshowsIQiQM5IqMz45uAcjJZm-99wfeJlPMNL49ZHgeA5o~rIoNt18ns0A01Qosd1pRjA38qPJXQudukNRcKTpnIk3J-bi26xa2c0vCZHOKNymlf61-mOSMP7Z3yZmZhTDTeNR1ATSrDmW60oT~wYtETjVPUMI2hi6mRxcywtgTZrbWcejzPzQM~Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison between the observed (first, third, and fifth columns) and reconstructed (second, fourth, and sixth columns) strong-lens systems.
