Horizontal white lines for each system are rulers showing 1 arcsec. The relative intensities of the bands have been adjusted for each lens system for clear visualization of the features in the system.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129897294/sty3397fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129897294\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/4/10.1093_mnras_sty3397/2/sty3397fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465403&Signature=rUpgIIIbJfdiVIyBgj5-Pb-w3glNJw9kSYHv~nLJ-ovtnOFRNnbWPe03rTiK5c2lk0mMeFqqv0ZtsJGS2pp16FcJitTSl8oR0RLSBAjs~cAZiAF7CPvihEo4vTwaBV8dqy-Z~vCZo7pVwdHdmFLY~nhzF7Bmcc23vjNsJa~dKwDViqE4korSoduYGl7mfbh3BKUC4mSrM6cIzlIv4BFgM9FhOqxmuN~gVE7OoxnvH8FIgF~D15WUR1dcMx63v0u0ML-rBv7CnQN-va4jiuBL156f4PToIY1rtqnY21cIw8yAfhWoDKGFwlRv9D2Nx43GlMPW9pqGluiXoOwaHKNpPw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129897294&ar=5251838&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison between the observed (first, third, and fifth columns) and reconstructed (second, fourth, and sixth columns) strong-lens systems. The three <em>HST</em> bands: F160W, F814W, and F475X are used in the red, green, and blue channels, respectively, to create the red-green-blue (RGB) images. Horizontal white lines for each system are rulers showing 1 arcsec. The relative intensities of the bands have been adjusted for each lens system for clear visualization of the features in the system.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129897295 id=\"129897295\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2-1>2.2.1 PS J0147+4630</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This quad was serendipitously discovered from the Panoramic Survey Telescope and Rapid Response System (Pan-STARRS) survey (Berghea et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The source redshift is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>s</sub> = 2.341\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.001 (Lee <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and the deflector redshift is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>d</sub> = 0.5716\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0004 (Lee <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Initial models from the Pan-STARRS data suggest a relatively large external shear \u03b3<sub>ext</sub> \u223c 0.13.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129897297 id=\"129897297\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2-2>2.2.2 SDSS J0248+1913</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This lens system was discovered in Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) imaging data using the morphology-independent Gaussian-mixture-model supervised-machine-learning technique described in Ostrovski et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) applied to SDSS <em>u, g</em>, and <em>i</em>, and <em>Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer</em> (<em>WISE</em>) <em>W</em>1 and <em>W</em>2 catalogue level photometry (Ostrovski et\u00a0al., in preparation). The lensing nature was confirmed via optical spectroscopy with the Echellette Spectrograph and Imager (ESI) on the Keck telescope in 2016 December prior to the <em>HST</em> observations presented here and will be described in Ostrovski et\u00a0al. (in preparation). Delchambre et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) report the independent discovery of this spectroscopically confirmed lensed system as a lensed quasar candidate using <em>Gaia</em> observations. The lens system resides in a dense environment with several other galaxies within close proximity. Part of the lensed arc from the extended source is noticeable in the F160W band in IR.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129897299 id=\"129897299\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2-3>2.2.3 ATLAS J0259\u20131635</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This lens system was discovered in VLT Survey Telescope (VST)-ATLAS survey from candidates selected with quasar-like <em>WISE</em> colours (Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib110\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib110\" data-open=\"bib110\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). The source for this system is at redshift <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>s</sub> = 2.16 (Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib110\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib110\" data-open=\"bib110\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129897301 id=\"129897301\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2-4>2.2.4 DES J0405\u20133308</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The discovery of this system is reported by Anguita et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). A complete or partial Einstein ring is noticeable in all the <em>HST</em> bands. The source redshift is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>s</sub> = 1.713\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.001 (Anguita et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129897303 id=\"129897303\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2-5>2.2.5 DES J0408\u20135354</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This system was discovered in the DES Year 1 data (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Diehl et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Lin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The deflector redshift is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>d</sub> = 0.597 and the quasar redshift is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>s</sub> = 2.375 (Lin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). This is a very complex lens system with multiple lensed arcs noticeable in addition to the quasar images. The sources of the lensed arcs can be components in the same source plane as the lensed quasar or they can be at different redshifts. This system has measured time-delays between the quasar images: \u0394<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub> = \u2212112\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02.1\u00a0d, \u0394<em>t</em><sub>AD</sub> = \u2212155.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a012.8\u00a0d, and \u0394<em>t</em><sub>BD</sub> = \u221242.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a017.6\u00a0d (Courbin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129897305 id=\"129897305\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2-6>2.2.6 DES J0420\u20134037</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This lens system was discovered in DES imaging data using the morphology-independent Gaussian-mixture-model supervised-machine-learning technique described in Ostrovski et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) applied to DES <em>g, r</em> and <em>i</em>, Visible and Infrared Survey Telescope for Astronomy (VISTA) <em>J</em> and <em>K</em>, and <em>WISE W</em>1 and <em>W</em>2 catalogue level photometry (Ostrovski et al., in preparation). Several small knots are noticeable near the quasar images that are possibly multiple images of extra components in the source plane.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129897307 id=\"129897307\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2-7>2.2.7 PS J0630\u20131201</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This system is a five-image lensed quasar system (Ostrovski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). The discovery was the result of a lens search from <em>Gaia</em> data from a selection of lens candidates from Pan-STARRS and <em>WISE</em>. The source redshift is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>s</sub> = 3.34 (Ostrovski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129897309 id=\"129897309\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2-8>2.2.8 SDSS J1251+2935</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This quad was discovered from the SDSS Quasar Lens Search (SQLS; Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) (Kayo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). The source redshift is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>s</sub> = 0.802 and the deflector redshift is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>d</sub> = 0.410 measured from the SDSS spectra (Kayo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129897311 id=\"129897311\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2-9>2.2.9 SDSS J1330+1810</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This lens system was also discovered from the SQLS (Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). The redshifts of the deflector and the source are <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>d</sub> = 0.373 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>s</sub> = 1.393, respectively (Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129897313 id=\"129897313\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2-10>2.2.10 SDSS J1433+6007</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This lens system was discovered in the SDSS data release 12 photometric catalogue (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>). The redshifts of the source and deflector are <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>s</sub> = 2.737\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.003 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>d</sub> = 0.407\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.002, respectively (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129897315 id=\"129897315\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2-11>2.2.11 PS J1606\u22122333</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This quad was discovered from <em>Gaia</em> observations through a candidate search with quasar-like <em>WISE</em> colours over the Pan-STARRS footprint (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). The main deflector has a noticeable companion near the southmost image.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129897317 id=\"129897317\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2-12>2.2.12 DES J2038\u22124008</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This lens system was discovered from a combined search in <em>WISE</em> and <em>Gaia</em> over the DES footprint (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018c</a>). The deflector and the source redshifts are <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>d</sub> = 0.230\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.002 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>s</sub> = 0.777\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.001, respectively (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018c</a>). This system has an intricate Einstein ring with complex features from the extended quasar host galaxy.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129897319 id=\"129897319\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2-13>2.2.13 WISE J2344\u22123056</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This lens system was discovered in the VST-ATLAS survey (Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib109\" data-open=\"bib109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). This is a small-size quad with reported maximum image separation \u223c1.1\u00a0arcsec. Several small and faint blobs are in close proximity, two of which are particularly noticeable near the north and east images.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=129897321 id=\"129897321\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 LENS MODELLING</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">To devise a uniform approach that will suit a wide range of quads that vary in size, configuration, light profiles, etc., we need to choose from the most general models for the lens mass profile and the light distributions. It is often required to fine-tune the choice of models by adding complexities to the lens model in a case-by-case basis to suit the purpose of the specific science driver of an investigator. However, such detailed lens-modelling is outside of the scope of this paper. We only require our models to satisfactorily (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\chi ^2_{\\rm red} \\sim 1$|\u2060</span>) fit the data while being general enough to be applicable to a wide variety of lens systems.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the publicly available software package <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstronomy</span><sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> (Birrer &amp; Amara <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>, based on Birrer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) to model the quads in our sample. Prior to this work, <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstronomy</span> was used to measure the Hubble constant (Birrer, Amara &amp; Refregier <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) and to quantify lensing substructure (Birrer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). We first adopt the simplest yet general set of profiles to model the deflector mass and light, and the source-light distributions (e.g. Sections\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.2</a>). Then, we run a particle swarm optimization (PSO) routine through <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstronomy</span> to find the maximum of the likelihood function. After the PSO routine, we check for the goodness-of-fit of the best-fitting model. If the adopted profiles cannot produce an acceptable fit to the data, we gradually add more mass or light profiles to account for extra complexities in the lens system, e.g. presence of satellites, complex structure near the Einstein ring, or extra lensed source components. We run the PSO routine after each addition of complexity until a set of adopted mass and light profiles can produce an acceptable model. Next, we obtain the posterior probability distribution functions (PDFs) of the model parameters using a Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) routine. The PSO and MCMC routines in <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstronomy</span> utilize the <span class=\"small-caps\">cosmohammer</span> package (Akeret et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). <span class=\"small-caps\">cosmohammer</span> itself embeds <span class=\"small-caps\">emcee</span> (Foreman-Mackey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), which is an affine-invariant ensemble sampler for MCMC (Goodman &amp; Weare <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) written in <span class=\"small-caps\">python</span>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we first describe the profiles used to parametrize the mass and light distributions. Then, we explain the decision tree of the modelling procedure.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=129897325 id=\"129897325\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Mass profile parametrization</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We adopt a power-law elliptical mass distribution (PEMD) for the lens mass profile. This profile is parametrized as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\kappa = \\frac{3-\\gamma }{2} \\left(\\frac{\\theta _{\\rm E}}{\\sqrt{q\\theta _1^2 + \\theta _2^2/q}} \\right)^{\\gamma - 1},\r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>where \u03b3 is the power-law slope, \u03b8<sub>E</sub> is the Einstein radius, <em>q</em> is the axial ratio. The coordinates (\u03b8<sub>1</sub>, \u03b8<sub>2</sub>) depend on position angle \u03d5 through a rotational transformation of the on-sky coordinates that aligns the coordinate axes along the major and minor axes.</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We also add an external shear profile parametrized by two parameters, \u03b3<sub>1</sub> and \u03b3<sub>2</sub>. The external-shear magnitude \u03b3<sub>ext</sub> and angle \u03d5<sub>ext</sub> are related to these parameters by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\gamma _{\\rm ext} = \\sqrt{\\gamma _1^2 + \\gamma _2^2}, \\ \\ \\tan 2 \\phi _{\\rm ext} = \\frac{\\gamma _2}{\\gamma _1}.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">If there is a secondary deflector or a satellite of the main deflector, we choose an isothermal elliptical mass distribution (IEMD), which is a PEMD with the power-law slope \u03b3 fixed to 2.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=129897329 id=\"129897329\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Light profile parametrization</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We choose the elliptical S\u00e9rsic function (S\u00e9rsic <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib112\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib112\" data-open=\"bib112\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1968</a>) to model the deflector light profile. The S\u00e9rsic function is parametrized as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nI(\\theta _1, \\theta _2) = I_{\\rm e} \\exp \\left[ -k \\left\\lbrace \\left(\\frac{\\sqrt{\\theta _1^2 + \\theta _2^2/q_{\\rm L}^2}}{\\theta _{\\rm eff}} \\right)^{1/n_{\\rm Sersic}} - 1\\right\\rbrace \\right].\r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div>Here, <em>I</em><sub>e</sub> is the amplitude, <em>k</em> is a constant that normalizes \u03b8<sub>eff</sub> so that it is the half-light radius, <em>q</em><sub>L</sub> is the axial ratio, and <em>n</em><sub>S\u00e9rsic</sub> is the S\u00e9rsic index. The coordinates (\u03b8<sub>1</sub>, \u03b8<sub>2</sub>) also depend on the position angle \u03d5<sub>L</sub> that rotationally transforms the on-sky coordinates to align the coordinate axes with the major and minor axes. We add a \u2018uniform\u2019 light profile parametrized by only one parameter, the amplitude, that can capture unaccounted flux from the lens by a single S\u00e9rsic profile.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The circular S\u00e9rsic function (with <em>q</em><sub>L</sub> = 1, \u03d5<sub>L</sub> = 0) is adopted to model the host-galaxy-light distribution. We limit \u03b8<sub>eff</sub> &gt; 0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>04 (which is the pixel size in the UVIS bands) on the source plane to prevent the S\u00e9rsic profile to be too pointy effectively mimicking a point source. For a typical source redshift <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>s</sub> = 2, 0.04\u00a0arcsec corresponds to \u223c0.33\u00a0kpc. This is a reasonable lower limit for the size of a lensed source hosting a supermassive black hole. If there are complex structures in the lensed arcs that cannot be fully captured by a simple S\u00e9rsic profile, we add a basis set of shapelets (Refregier <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Birrer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) on top of the S\u00e9rsic profile to reconstruct the source-light distribution. The basis set is parametrized by maximum order <em>n</em><sub>max</sub>, and a characteristic scale \u03b2. The number of shapelets is given by (<em>n</em><sub>max</sub> + 1)(<em>n</em><sub>max</sub> + 2)/2.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The quasar images are modelled with point sources with a point spread function (PSF) on the image plane.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=129897333 id=\"129897333\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Modelling procedure</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We model the quads in a general framework to simultaneously fit the data from all three <em>HST</em> bands. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> illustrates the flow of the modelling procedure. We describe the nodes of this flow chart below. Each node is marked with a lowercase letter. Some of the decision nodes in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> are self-explanatory and need no further elaboration.</p>                        <a id=\"129897335\" scrollto-destination=\"129897335\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/4/10.1093_mnras_sty3397/2/m_sty3397fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465403&amp;Signature=hswkx2CFx53lniM87j4S5P2n4Dgyv-pf-VFaQ99Xt-VrM7ESPi9CeADGeh9rOXtwHZUalCfATrRle33IOmkgtRRnFG-fafzAdaKuCDPrsis571PARn-fONT3f0bW7Oe8-qnYVSmy2l3cyabdtotID0FdA8agRZqFkE~MPusFx1p29OVTx7ZjOPGevhzvx6JhHikxP0YNWjlWMDUSJxZsnPXOBqBurNJ2tXjU8cka3M9Tf1tE4OIBjl7wdxm4r~FVO53VhSWnf5PNoifYzfHhEtO5poSKnjyD5I-5~GdwbfDv3C33D~5c3wNYUl-MEQoFftGQtHz2XCzDlGmOJXX2tw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Flowchart showing the decision tree for uniform modelling of quads to simultaneously fit multiband data. After the initial set-up (node a), the fitting is first done only with one band (node b) to iteratively choose the necessary level of complexity in the mass and light profiles (nodes d, e, f, g, h, k, l). A proposed model is accepted, if the power-law slope \u03b3 does not diverge to a bound of the allowed range (nodes j) and the p-value $\\gtrsim 10^{-8}$ for the fit (nodes c, j). After deciding upon a set of profiles to simultaneously model the multiband data (node i), the uncertainties on the model parameters are obtained by running a MCMC routine (node m).\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129897335/sty3397fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129897335\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/4/10.1093_mnras_sty3397/2/sty3397fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465403&Signature=MMzsafK0ydQYq~pbjFh4yxZzDXR~yC4VOfz5Qmz3NdTuARWy~baBXWxcLi161HbwhutYQTbb7WBy4LGdE5EoJ8kY83tdneXghnUfl88iRQ1gpbKRvyD6w9sDpBEF1E1MpDENil~AQOvHUKAyGiFV1Un2ExUOy2Omgrqo7gn1nLTs0q~q334AJYKyAm15U2puyWzTJ78kxRnBEIRD7tV6tTf2Zud2fuWZ7lje2bqDsh2TpdTkM80V0A2pEdNT45FcPpqYU~75AYnnNhQZG74ggRIJWqH3YnbjRm~LRD2LvRCGw6QVCvJ5BiHOoqaL933gRbVcoYo9l1QyifECMrChPg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129897335&ar=5251838&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Flowchart showing the decision tree for uniform modelling of quads to simultaneously fit multiband data. After the initial set-up (node a), the fitting is first done only with one band (node b) to iteratively choose the necessary level of complexity in the mass and light profiles (nodes d, e, f, g, h, k, l). A proposed model is accepted, if the power-law slope \u03b3 does not diverge to a bound of the allowed range (nodes j) and the <em>p</em>-value <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\gtrsim 10^{-8}$|</span> for the fit (nodes c, j). After deciding upon a set of profiles to simultaneously model the multiband data (node i), the uncertainties on the model parameters are obtained by running a MCMC routine (node m).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/4/10.1093_mnras_sty3397/2/m_sty3397fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465403&amp;Signature=hswkx2CFx53lniM87j4S5P2n4Dgyv-pf-VFaQ99Xt-VrM7ESPi9CeADGeh9rOXtwHZUalCfATrRle33IOmkgtRRnFG-fafzAdaKuCDPrsis571PARn-fONT3f0bW7Oe8-qnYVSmy2l3cyabdtotID0FdA8agRZqFkE~MPusFx1p29OVTx7ZjOPGevhzvx6JhHikxP0YNWjlWMDUSJxZsnPXOBqBurNJ2tXjU8cka3M9Tf1tE4OIBjl7wdxm4r~FVO53VhSWnf5PNoifYzfHhEtO5poSKnjyD5I-5~GdwbfDv3C33D~5c3wNYUl-MEQoFftGQtHz2XCzDlGmOJXX2tw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Flowchart showing the decision tree for uniform modelling of quads to simultaneously fit multiband data. After the initial set-up (node a), the fitting is first done only with one band (node b) to iteratively choose the necessary level of complexity in the mass and light profiles (nodes d, e, f, g, h, k, l). A proposed model is accepted, if the power-law slope \u03b3 does not diverge to a bound of the allowed range (nodes j) and the p-value $\\gtrsim 10^{-8}$ for the fit (nodes c, j). After deciding upon a set of profiles to simultaneously model the multiband data (node i), the uncertainties on the model parameters are obtained by running a MCMC routine (node m).\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129897335/sty3397fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129897335\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/4/10.1093_mnras_sty3397/2/sty3397fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465403&Signature=MMzsafK0ydQYq~pbjFh4yxZzDXR~yC4VOfz5Qmz3NdTuARWy~baBXWxcLi161HbwhutYQTbb7WBy4LGdE5EoJ8kY83tdneXghnUfl88iRQ1gpbKRvyD6w9sDpBEF1E1MpDENil~AQOvHUKAyGiFV1Un2ExUOy2Omgrqo7gn1nLTs0q~q334AJYKyAm15U2puyWzTJ78kxRnBEIRD7tV6tTf2Zud2fuWZ7lje2bqDsh2TpdTkM80V0A2pEdNT45FcPpqYU~75AYnnNhQZG74ggRIJWqH3YnbjRm~LRD2LvRCGw6QVCvJ5BiHOoqaL933gRbVcoYo9l1QyifECMrChPg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129897335&ar=5251838&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Flowchart showing the decision tree for uniform modelling of quads to simultaneously fit multiband data. After the initial set-up (node a), the fitting is first done only with one band (node b) to iteratively choose the necessary level of complexity in the mass and light profiles (nodes d, e, f, g, h, k, l). A proposed model is accepted, if the power-law slope \u03b3 does not diverge to a bound of the allowed range (nodes j) and the <em>p</em>-value <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\gtrsim 10^{-8}$|</span> for the fit (nodes c, j). After deciding upon a set of profiles to simultaneously model the multiband data (node i), the uncertainties on the model parameters are obtained by running a MCMC routine (node m).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>a. Initial set-up:</strong> We first pre-process the data in each band. A cut-out with an appropriate field-of-view covering the lens and nearby environment from the whole image is chosen. The background flux estimated by <span class=\"small-caps\">SExtractor</span> (Bertin &amp; Arnouts 1996) from the whole image is subtracted from the cutout. We also select four or more stars from the <em>HST</em> images to estimate the initial PSF in each band. A circular mask with a suitable radius is chosen to only include the deflector-light distribution, and the lensed quasar-images and arcs. If there is a nearby galaxy or a star, we mask it out unless we specifically choose to model the light profile of a satellite or companion galaxy, e.g. for DES J0408\u22125354, PS J0630\u22121201, SDSS J1433+6007, and PS J1606\u22122333. As PS J0630\u22121201 is a five-image lens, we allow the model the flexibility to produce more than four images.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>b. Fit the \u2018most informative\u2019 band:</strong> It is important to judiciously initiate any optimization routine, such as the PSO, to efficiently find the global extremum. Finding the global maximum of the joint likelihood from all the bands together from a random initial point is often very expensive in terms of time and computational resource. Therefore, we first only fit the \u2018most informative\u2019 band to iteratively select the light and mass profiles necessary to account for the lens complexity. In this study, we choose F814W as the \u2018most informative\u2019 band. It is easier to decompose the deflector and the source-light distributions in the F814W band than in the F160W band as the deflector does not have a large flux near or beyond the Einstein ring. The resolution in the F814W band is also twice as high as in the F160W band. Furthermore, the deflector flux in the F475X band is often too small to reliably model the deflector-light distribution without a good prior. At first, we fix the power-law slope for the lens mass model at \u03b3 = 2 (i.e. the isothermal case). With each consecutive PSO routine, we narrow down the search region in the parameter space around the maximum of the likelihood. After each PSO routine, we iteratively reconstruct the PSF with the modelled-extended-light subtracted quasar images themselves. This is performed iteratively such that the extended light model updates its model with the new PSF to avoid biases and overconstraints on the PSF model. Similar procedures have been used in Chen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), Birrer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), and Wong et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib141\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib141\" data-open=\"bib141\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The details are described in Birrer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_933_1547262377717\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_933_1547262377717\" data-open=\"bib1_933_1547262377717\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) and the reconstruction routines are part of <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstronomy</span>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>c. Good fit?</strong> We check for the goodness of fit by calculating the <em>p</em>-value for the total \u03c7<sup>2</sup> and degrees of freedom. We set <em>p</em>-value <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\gtrsim 10^{-8}$|</span> as a criterion to accept a model. This low <em>p</em>-value is enough to point out substantial inadequacies in the model while applicable to the wide variety of the lens systems in our sample. Implementing a higher <em>p</em>-value would require noise-level modelling that is hard to achieve in a uniform framework. The total \u03c7<sup>2</sup> in this node is computed from the residuals in the F814W band only.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>e. Add satellite mass profile:</strong> We add an IEMD for the satellite or companion mass profile. The light distribution of the satellite is modelled with an elliptical S\u00e9rsic profile. The initial centroid of the satellite is chosen approximately at the centre of the brightest pixel in the satellite.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>g. Add extra source component:</strong> If there are extra lensed source components, e.g. blobs or arcs, that are not part of the primary source structure near the Einstein ring, we add extra light profiles in the same source plane of the lensed quasar. We only add one light profile for each set of conjugate components. It is easier to identify and constrain the positions of additional source components on the image plane. Among the identifiable conjugate components from visual inspection, if one component is a smaller blob, and the others form arcs, we choose the blob\u2019s position in the image plane as the initial guess. First, we only add one circular S\u00e9rsic profile for each additional source component. For the second visit to this node, i.e. there is unaccounted structure or extra light near the additional lensed source components, we add shapelets with <em>n</em><sub>max</sub> = 3 on top of the S\u00e9rsic profile. For each subsequent visit, we increase <em>n</em><sub>max</sub> by 2.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>h. Add shapelets to source-light profile:</strong> If there are structures near the Einstein ring, we add a basis set of shapelets on top of the S\u00e9rsic function to the primary source-light profile. We first add shapelets with <em>n</em><sub>max</sub> = 10 and increase <em>n</em><sub>max</sub> by 5 for each future visit to this node. The characteristic scale \u03b2 of the shapelets is initiated with the best fit \u03b8<sub>eff</sub> of the S\u00e9rsic profile for the source.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>i. Fit all bands simultaneously:</strong> Before fitting all the bands simultaneously it is important to check astrometric alignment between the bands and correct accordingly if there is a misalignment. We align the data from the IR channel (F160W) with those from the UVIS band (F814W and F475X) by matching the positions of the four lensed quasar images. After that, we run PSO routines to fit all the bands simultaneously. Each PSO routine is followed by one iterative PSF reconstruction routine. During simultaneous fitting, only the intensities of the light profiles and shapelets are varied independently for different bands. All the other parameters, such as scalelength, ellipticity, position angle and S\u00e9rsic index, are set to be common across wavelengths, which is a common practice for simultaneous fitting of multiband data (e.g. Stoughton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Lackner &amp; Gunn <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). As a result, for the case of a single S\u00e9rsic profile the best-fitting parameters are effectively an average over the wavelengths. However, we find the resultant best-fitting parameters from the simultaneous fitting to be within 1\u03c3 systematic+statistical uncertainty of the ones from the individual fits of different bands for one representative system (DES J0405\u22123308) from our sample. Therefore, we assume that setting these parameters to be common across wavelengths is sufficient for the purpose of this study. For the case of shapelets or double S\u00e9rsic profile, the relative intensities of the shapelets or S\u00e9rsic components can freely vary across bands. This allows for more complex morphological variation across wavelengths and makes our assumption even more reasonable.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>j. Good fit?</strong> We check for the goodness of fit with the same criteria described in node c. In this node, the total \u03c7<sup>2</sup> is computed from the residuals in all the three bands. Moreover, we check that the power-law slope \u03b3 has not diverged to the bound of the allowed values when \u03b3 is relaxed in node i. This might happen if there is not enough complexity in the adopted model to reconstruct the observed fluxes. We also check if there is lens flux unaccounted by the single S\u00e9rsic profile. If the total flux in the \u2018uniform\u2019 light profile within the effective radius is more than one per cent of that for the elliptical S\u00e9rsic profile, we decide that there is unaccounted lens flux. This can particularly happen in the F160W band as the lens light is more extended in the IR than in the UVIS channels and two concentric S\u00e9rsic functions provide a better fit to the lens light (Claeskens et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib120\" data-open=\"bib120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). If there is no unaccounted lens light, we discard the \u2018uniform\u2019 profile from the set of lens-light profiles before moving to node m.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>l. Add second S\u00e9rsic function to lens-light profile:</strong> If there is unaccounted lens flux, we discard the \u2018uniform\u2019 light profile and add a second S\u00e9rsic function on top of the first one with the same centroid. We fix the S\u00e9rsic indices for the two S\u00e9rsic profiles to <em>n</em><sub>S\u00e9rsic</sub> = 4 (de Vaucouleurs profile) and <em>n</em><sub>S\u00e9rsic</sub> = 1 (exponential). We fix these S\u00e9rsic indices for numerical stability. These profile fits should not be interpreted as bulge\u2013disc decompositions. For a proper bulge\u2013disc decomposition, more robust methods should be adopted to detect the presence of multiple components, e.g. Bayesian model comparison (D\u2019Souza et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) and axis-ratio variation technique (Oh, Greene &amp; Lackner <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>m. Run MCMC:</strong> If the PSO fitting sequence finds an acceptable model for the quad, we run an MCMC routine. The initial positions of the walkers are centred around the best fit found by the PSO fitting sequence.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>n. Finish:</strong> After the MCMC routine, we check for the convergence of the chain. We accept the chain as converged, if the total number of steps is \u223c10\u00a0times the autocorrelation length, and the median and variance of the walker positions at each step are stable for 1 autocorrelation length at the end of the chain. We then calculate the best-fitting value for each model parameter from the median of the walker positions at the last step. Similarly, 1\u03c3 confidence levels are computed from the 16th and 84th percentiles in the last step.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=129897347 id=\"129897347\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-4>3.4 Systematics</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We estimate the systematic uncertainties of the lens model parameters by marginalizing over several numerical settings. We performed the modelling technique described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.3</a> with 11 different numerical settings: varying the lens-mask size, varying the mask size for extra quasar-images for PSF reconstruction, varying the sampling resolution of the reconstructed <em>HST</em> image, without PSF reconstruction, and with different realisations of the reconstructed PSF. We checked for systematics for the lens system SDSS J0248+1913. This system was chosen for two reasons: (i) this system has relatively fainter arc compared to the point source and deflector brightness, thus providing a conservative estimate of the systematics, and (ii) the modelling procedure is one of the simplest ones that enables running the modelling procedure numerous times with different settings in relatively less time. We assume the systematics are the same order of magnitude for the other lens systems in the sample.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=129897349 id=\"129897349\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 RESULTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we first describe the lens models and report the model parameters along with some derived parameters for all the quads. Then, we investigate the alignment between the mass and light profiles and report our findings. In Appendices\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec6\">A</a>\u2013\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec8\">C</a>, we report additional inferred lens model parameters that are not directly relevant for the scientific investigation carried out here but may be of interest to some readers, especially in planning future follow-up and observations.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=129897351 id=\"129897351\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Efficiency of the uniform framework</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">All the 13 quads are reliably (<em>p</em>-value \u223c 1; Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) modelled following the uniform approach described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.3</a>. The framework was designed and tuned from the experience gained from uniformly modelling the first ten observed quads in the sample. The three quads, SDSS J1251+2935, SDSS J1330+1810 and SDSS J1433+6007, were observed after the design phase. We effectively modelled these three lenses implementing the general framework, which validates its effectiveness. The total investigator time spent for these two lenses is \u223c3\u00a0h per lens including data reduction, initial set-up and quality control of the model outputs. The number of CPU hours (on state-of-the-art machines<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">3</a></sup>) per system ranges between 50 and 500 depending on the complexity of the model.</p>                        <a id=\"129897353\" J2344\u22123056\u00a0</td><td>PEMD\u00a0</td><td>Double elliptical S\u00e9rsic\u00a0</td><td>S\u00e9rsic\u00a0</td><td>1.0\u00a0</td><td>abcdfhbcijmn\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>Shapelets (<em>n</em><sub>max</sub> = 10)\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>Point source (image plane)\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DES J0405\u22123308\u00a0</td><td>PEMD\u00a0</td><td>Elliptical S\u00e9rsic\u00a0</td><td>S\u00e9rsic\u00a0</td><td>1.0\u00a0</td><td>abcijmn\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>Point source (image plane)\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DES J0408\u22125354\u00a0</td><td>PEMD\u00a0</td><td>Elliptical S\u00e9rsic\u00a0</td><td>S\u00e9rsic\u00a0</td><td>1.0\u00a0</td><td>abcdebcdfgbcdfgbcijkdf\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>IEMD<sup><em>c</em></sup>\u00a0</td><td>Elliptical S\u00e9rsic<sup><em>c</em></sup>\u00a0</td><td>Shapelets (<em>n</em><sub>max</sub> = 10)\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>gbcijkdfhbcijmn\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>S\u00e9rsic<sup><em>c</em></sup>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>Shapelets<sup><em>c</em></sup> (<em>n</em><sub>max</sub> = class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>.<sup><em>a</em></sup>The <em>p</em>-value is for the combined \u03c7<sup>2</sup> from all three bands.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf2\"></span><div source.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/129897353\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=129897354 id=\"129897354\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Lens models</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The set of profiles chosen through the decision tree for modelling the quads along with the corresponding <em>p</em>-values are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. We show a breakdown of the best-fitting models in each band for the quads, SDSS J0248+1913, DES J0408-5354, SDSS J1251+2935, SDSS J1433+6007, as examples, in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. Model breakdowns for the rest of lenses are provided in Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec9\">D</a>. We show the red-green-blue (RGB) images produced from the <em>HST</em> data alongside the reconstructed RGB images for all the quads in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"129897356\" scrollto-destination=\"129897356\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/4/10.1093_mnras_sty3397/2/m_sty3397fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465403&amp;Signature=waz0wDgywqDdI6XvORzYSRatCjEZqXaX-XxsI-oL~xfTmZIBIKMxszVCV0Ye-0Nex2LcyWRaBbe463wMu5DlEHPGZnnl-Q8DWW1rVedmtFjM-l4gxC9X4ar5vfWXZFM4DveSH~GEfUUzn5F1Jw1NVy4TTAzUbL7fNcqkx-sHj~5E0KDpkZ8wGt~KUxlHjtwDDNVTH5lK95FE4vQlHV0pIiY9Gv2PULMOcm1apHuPJWCWmKxYlEJ8ZsHU6j9URCoHhvrDArsREPZaG1XbaBnGgVIJJnV18TaOp8u2Db7d30pIkxLp0fELRYhso3FAZ0EfQ-ktV-FvSRUQnoCAKSwWDA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Best-fitting models for SDSS J0248+1913 (top left), DES J0408-5354 (top right), SDSS J1251+2935 (bottom left), and SDSS J1433+6007 (bottom right). The first three rows for each lens system show the observed image, reconstructed lens image, and the normalized residuals in three HST bands: F160W, F814W, and F475X, respectively. The fourth row shows the reconstructed source in the F160W band, the convergence, and the magnification model. The models for the rest of the sample are shown in Appendix\u00a0D (Figs\u00a0D1 and\u00a0D2).\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129897356/sty3397fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129897356\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/4/10.1093_mnras_sty3397/2/sty3397fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465403&Signature=HbmgUX71cNLz7Wob8X-5ejtGWo5sOqhMuw~1th-cv3ethS3wB7fHQZoHuu4luYRQUfA2lljndOgqTVNyyeMHO1xjWMldmkH4DruTS6v1FpfuIrnuVv52JZm-dFJPNM-e67LtvS~brjpEX~0ZEwzWBe2PWTbSy-yc0RJbM3L9VTyPg3Mo3oijKaN08xTN0N4D4L8nacECR8CQReOic2ks-kykhvpWjJNX0Fmyvh~y1zjhxUmfHo6yFtdlSu9NwI4tPY6qK8kXeTTorFgOjYlBNcbWBNUYg8mz78VlUERvJUpzcZra6CuLGPAP-VgUcFMbcQI8nXwxR9AvP91ZrdRjlg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129897356&ar=5251838&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Best-fitting models for SDSS J0248+1913 (top left), DES J0408-5354 (top right), SDSS J1251+2935 (bottom left), and SDSS J1433+6007 (bottom right). The fourth row shows the reconstructed source in the F160W band, the convergence, and the magnification model. The models for the rest of the sample are shown in Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec9\">D</a> (Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figd1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figd1\" data-open=\"figd1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">D1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figd2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figd2\" data-open=\"figd2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">D2</a>).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/4/10.1093_mnras_sty3397/2/m_sty3397fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465403&amp;Signature=waz0wDgywqDdI6XvORzYSRatCjEZqXaX-XxsI-oL~xfTmZIBIKMxszVCV0Ye-0Nex2LcyWRaBbe463wMu5DlEHPGZnnl-Q8DWW1rVedmtFjM-l4gxC9X4ar5vfWXZFM4DveSH~GEfUUzn5F1Jw1NVy4TTAzUbL7fNcqkx-sHj~5E0KDpkZ8wGt~KUxlHjtwDDNVTH5lK95FE4vQlHV0pIiY9Gv2PULMOcm1apHuPJWCWmKxYlEJ8ZsHU6j9URCoHhvrDArsREPZaG1XbaBnGgVIJJnV18TaOp8u2Db7d30pIkxLp0fELRYhso3FAZ0EfQ-ktV-FvSRUQnoCAKSwWDA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Best-fitting models for SDSS J0248+1913 (top left), DES J0408-5354 (top right), SDSS J1251+2935 (bottom left), and SDSS J1433+6007 (bottom right). The first three rows for each lens system show the observed image, reconstructed lens image, and the normalized residuals in three HST bands: F160W, F814W, and F475X, respectively. The fourth row shows the reconstructed source in the F160W band, the convergence, and the magnification model. The models for the rest of the sample are shown in Appendix\u00a0D (Figs\u00a0D1 and\u00a0D2).\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129897356/sty3397fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129897356\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/4/10.1093_mnras_sty3397/2/sty3397fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465403&Signature=HbmgUX71cNLz7Wob8X-5ejtGWo5sOqhMuw~1th-cv3ethS3wB7fHQZoHuu4luYRQUfA2lljndOgqTVNyyeMHO1xjWMldmkH4DruTS6v1FpfuIrnuVv52JZm-dFJPNM-e67LtvS~brjpEX~0ZEwzWBe2PWTbSy-yc0RJbM3L9VTyPg3Mo3oijKaN08xTN0N4D4L8nacECR8CQReOic2ks-kykhvpWjJNX0Fmyvh~y1zjhxUmfHo6yFtdlSu9NwI4tPY6qK8kXeTTorFgOjYlBNcbWBNUYg8mz78VlUERvJUpzcZra6CuLGPAP-VgUcFMbcQI8nXwxR9AvP91ZrdRjlg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129897356&ar=5251838&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Best-fitting models for SDSS J0248+1913 (top left), DES J0408-5354 (top right), SDSS J1251+2935 (bottom left), and SDSS J1433+6007 (bottom right). The first three rows for each lens system show the observed image, reconstructed lens image, and the normalized residuals in three <em>HST</em> bands: F160W, F814W, and F475X, respectively. The fourth row shows the reconstructed source in the F160W band, the convergence, and the magnification model. The models for the rest of the sample are shown in Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec9\">D</a> (Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figd1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figd1\" data-open=\"figd1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">D1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figd2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figd2\" data-open=\"figd2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">D2</a>).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We checked the robustness of the estimated lens model parameters with and without PSF reconstructions. We find the Einstein radius \u03b8<sub>E</sub>, axial ratio <em>q</em>, mass position angle \u03d5, external shear \u03b3<sub>ext</sub>, and shear angle \u03d5<sub>ext</sub> to be robustly (within 1\u03c3 systematic+statistical uncertainty) estimated. However, the power-law slope \u03b3 is affected by \u22651\u03c3 systematic+statistical uncertainty due to deviations of the reconstructed PSF. This is expected as \u03b3 depends on the thickness of the Einstein ring and this thickness in the reconstructed model in turn depends on the PSF.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We investigated if setting the S\u00e9rsic radius and index of the source light profile common across wavelength bands biases the measurement of the power-law slope. For one representative system (DES J0405+3308) from our sample, we find the power-law slope from the individual fits of different bands to agree within 1\u03c3 systematic+statistical uncertainty of the one from the simultaneous fit. Therefore, we conclude that setting the scaling parameters of the source light profile except the intensity to be common across wavelengths does not significantly (&gt;1\u03c3) bias the power-law slope.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We checked if the lens model parameters are stable with increasing complexity in the model (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>). The stability of the Einstein radius \u03b8<sub>E</sub> and the external shear \u03b3<sub>ext</sub> improves if the mass profile of a satellite is explicitly modelled. For increasing complexity in modelling the source-light distribution, the power-law slope \u03b3, the Einstein radius \u03b8<sub>E</sub>, and the external convergence \u03b3<sub>ext</sub> are stable.</p>                        <a id=\"129897360\" scrollto-destination=\"129897360\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/4/10.1093_mnras_sty3397/2/m_sty3397fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465403&amp;Signature=fqd5QiPDdOThE1PapuFCrrjdXuLZiyMNgCokUZSMhRs7UVaEEdB0lKkBU-8t-kVdbtQHnFsX2u4UCZMOJnRJ1tbXRTN6FmmG2kkh93isF4oYrV3eVQi51Aqe9G9UqFDz4fK1fEGFMWylXoo1mt-JPOhjtDk1rXvl6Hdxb5Ba00YF17OWgMOMiQ9p-NGsC~NluQvnG-iopv7qxkNennC-RocN0CacyyhbTUFJRfplau4ep9kNXzVnaYKlTHiddFtL1BkK~xhAfRmnpmEyAcyX0xyI6GRkBGmbGIJQfK4l-Q3oHYZdgLHUlWnRJ7cH1~XNZadbmMfomQAOo1-h00D1rg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Stability of lens model parameters with increasing model complexity. The four panels show the power-law slope \u03b3, Einstein radius \u03b8E, external shear \u03b3ext, and logarithm of p-value of the reduced-\u03c72 of the model fit, top to bottom, along the decision-flow for the quad DES J0408\u20135354. The bottom-horizontal axis denotes the node identifiers along the decision flow as in Fig.\u00a02. Short descriptions for added profiles at corresponding points along the decision flow are shown along the top-horizontal axis. Solid-grey lines attached to the blue circles show 1\u03c3 systematic+statistical uncertainty. The dashed-grey line at the bottom panel marks the threshold p-value = 10\u22128 for accepting a model. The p-value decreases after crossing the threshold the first time due to addition of the other two bands for simultaneous fitting, which requires more complexity in the model.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129897360/sty3397fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129897360\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/4/10.1093_mnras_sty3397/2/sty3397fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465403&Signature=vvE95gaN1qbwPFqNLAHwc2uZ9gqsu9ZlMkxFdmXk3MMp-cSvZycSiZurzD3eWnVbfMZIGcvvwFPotdOIZ32i~ZDZkvKa1eFVZ1Ad~gLyEZ5d9wBpiYcCvMo8ETDFzCo0N9C2xUSiNSqWxArZc3kYeQdToqlsbPb~rOX04ILFTTxIK-s7YbcVlQX~eAuqtTmuQY3NqIc3VfULA5lCwgrHKTaiTbAG3cZb8VnRDqHgfJY5gLAg~7VeNTPfciHN0atOem8SZKIZvxefDCKFHPgpxx-xpDeBImZEBNB9HH3tLlabuLcKF7c6eY4RRUjJ-mYA3stNJWyRT1ijY-ToSwG6jw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129897360&ar=5251838&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Stability of lens model parameters with increasing model complexity. The four panels show the power-law slope \u03b3, Einstein radius \u03b8<sub>E</sub>, external shear \u03b3<sub>ext</sub>, and logarithm of <em>p</em>-value of the reduced-\u03c7<sup>2</sup> of the model fit, top to bottom, along the decision-flow for the quad DES J0408\u20135354. The bottom-horizontal axis denotes the node identifiers along the decision flow as in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. Short descriptions for added profiles at corresponding points along the decision flow are shown along the top-horizontal axis. Solid-grey lines attached to the blue circles show 1\u03c3 systematic+statistical uncertainty. The dashed-grey line at the bottom panel marks the threshold <em>p</em>-value = 10<sup>\u22128</sup> for accepting a model. The <em>p</em>-value decreases after crossing the threshold the first time due to addition of the other two bands for simultaneous fitting, which requires more complexity in the model.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/4/10.1093_mnras_sty3397/2/m_sty3397fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465403&amp;Signature=fqd5QiPDdOThE1PapuFCrrjdXuLZiyMNgCokUZSMhRs7UVaEEdB0lKkBU-8t-kVdbtQHnFsX2u4UCZMOJnRJ1tbXRTN6FmmG2kkh93isF4oYrV3eVQi51Aqe9G9UqFDz4fK1fEGFMWylXoo1mt-JPOhjtDk1rXvl6Hdxb5Ba00YF17OWgMOMiQ9p-NGsC~NluQvnG-iopv7qxkNennC-RocN0CacyyhbTUFJRfplau4ep9kNXzVnaYKlTHiddFtL1BkK~xhAfRmnpmEyAcyX0xyI6GRkBGmbGIJQfK4l-Q3oHYZdgLHUlWnRJ7cH1~XNZadbmMfomQAOo1-h00D1rg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Stability of lens model parameters with increasing model complexity. The four panels show the power-law slope \u03b3, Einstein radius \u03b8E, external shear \u03b3ext, and logarithm of p-value of the reduced-\u03c72 of the model fit, top to bottom, along the decision-flow for the quad DES J0408\u20135354. The bottom-horizontal axis denotes the node identifiers along the decision flow as in Fig.\u00a02. Short descriptions for added profiles at corresponding points along the decision flow are shown along the top-horizontal axis. Solid-grey lines attached to the blue circles show 1\u03c3 systematic+statistical uncertainty. The dashed-grey line at the bottom panel marks the threshold p-value = 10\u22128 for accepting a model. The p-value decreases after crossing the threshold the first time due to addition of the other two bands for simultaneous fitting, which requires more complexity in the model.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129897360/sty3397fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129897360\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/4/10.1093_mnras_sty3397/2/sty3397fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465403&Signature=vvE95gaN1qbwPFqNLAHwc2uZ9gqsu9ZlMkxFdmXk3MMp-cSvZycSiZurzD3eWnVbfMZIGcvvwFPotdOIZ32i~ZDZkvKa1eFVZ1Ad~gLyEZ5d9wBpiYcCvMo8ETDFzCo0N9C2xUSiNSqWxArZc3kYeQdToqlsbPb~rOX04ILFTTxIK-s7YbcVlQX~eAuqtTmuQY3NqIc3VfULA5lCwgrHKTaiTbAG3cZb8VnRDqHgfJY5gLAg~7VeNTPfciHN0atOem8SZKIZvxefDCKFHPgpxx-xpDeBImZEBNB9HH3tLlabuLcKF7c6eY4RRUjJ-mYA3stNJWyRT1ijY-ToSwG6jw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129897360&ar=5251838&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Stability of lens model parameters with increasing model complexity. The four panels show the power-law slope \u03b3, Einstein radius \u03b8<sub>E</sub>, external shear \u03b3<sub>ext</sub>, and logarithm of <em>p</em>-value of the reduced-\u03c7<sup>2</sup> of the model fit, top to bottom, along the decision-flow for the quad DES J0408\u20135354. The bottom-horizontal axis denotes the node identifiers along the decision flow as in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. Short descriptions for added profiles at corresponding points along the decision flow are shown along the top-horizontal axis. Solid-grey lines attached to the blue circles show 1\u03c3 systematic+statistical uncertainty. The dashed-grey line at the bottom panel marks the threshold <em>p</em>-value = 10<sup>\u22128</sup> for accepting a model. The <em>p</em>-value decreases after crossing the threshold the first time due to addition of the other two bands for simultaneous fitting, which requires more complexity in the model.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We report the lens model parameters: Einstein radius \u03b8<sub>E</sub>, power-law slope \u03b3, axial ratio <em>q</em>, position angle \u03d5, external shear \u03b3<sub>ext</sub>, and shear angle \u03d5<sub>ext</sub> and deflector light parameters: effective radius \u03b8<sub>eff</sub>, axial ratio <em>q</em><sub>L</sub>, and position angle \u03d5<sub>L</sub> in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. For the deflectors fitted with double S\u00e9rsic profiles, the ellipticity and position angles are computed by fitting isophotes to the double S\u00e9rsic light distribution. We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">photutils</span><sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">4</a></sup> package in <span class=\"small-caps\">python</span> for measuring the isophotes that implements an iterative method described by Jedrzejewski (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1987</a>). We tabulate the astrometric positions of the deflector galaxy and the quasar images in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. The apparent magnitudes of the deflector galaxy and the quasar images in each of the three <em>HST</em> bands are given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"129897362\" scrollto-destination=\"129897362\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lens model parameters. The reported uncertainties are systematic and statistical uncertainties added in quadrature.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>System name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" 22.51\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.10, 23.40 \u00b1 .04, and 24.77\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04 in the F160W, F814W, and F475X bands, respectively.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;
