      <h3 scrollto-destination=129897365 id=\"129897365\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>4.3 Alignment between mass and light distributions</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this subsection, we report our results on the alignment between the mass and light distributions in our sample of quads (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"129897367\" scrollto-destination=\"129897367\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/4/10.1093_mnras_sty3397/2/m_sty3397fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465403&amp;Signature=cI1qucA9-NDgMtJQ1-oANDUw987eZLksp3k7YunvUQ6Dvm~BLh8R4KEDE80R~7tuCLLsO8PAXCDgjS1sJJ7TqTy3AhyGzc84VKAmmdjeKIdS21tLDn7O7-gZq5USx~ZldCZSSwm5jnUDfg5W87BKdb7yEQN42X3ULfdI0XG7vT~PtlDYHkZZmtEESFhE3UIA9oimA-oHlX046VXkuUEB2brp4VKKT7aEr6Za2O4Y6rSpe9o-4duPHjgcF5lFQL4jkrbScky0tlg~oYbKbg1fZdGr9WwaoshRaPVeViStnW4PjbW79aKVwGBLRJdUPQdzTWd3fAtbkXikNfD2a-QF9g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Mass and light alignments in the deflector galaxies: comparison between (a) the mass and light centroids, (b) the axis ratios of the light and mass profiles, (c) the misalignment angle (between the mass and light profiles\u2019 position angles), (d) the misalignment angle and the external shear, and (e) the misalignment angle and the mass profile axial ratio. The thin-solid-grey lines attached to the data points show 1\u03c3 statistical uncertainty and the thick-solid-black bars annotated with \u2018sys.\u2019 in each figure shows the 1\u03c3 systematic uncertainty. The systematic uncertainty is estimated by marginalizing over various numerical settings for the system SDSS J0248+1913 as described in Section\u00a03.4. In (a) the solid-grey ellipse centred at (0, 0) shows the root-mean-square (rms) spread of \u0394RA and \u0394Dec. for nine lens systems excluding the systems with large deviations: PS J0147+4630, DES J0408\u22125354, and PS J0630\u22121201. This rms spread can be taken as the upper limit of the systematics. The dashed grey line traces the perfect 1-to-1 correlation in (b) and the zero misalignment in (c) to aid visualisation. The centres of the mass and light distributions match very well (a). The systems with large offsets between the mass and light centroids have satellites or comparable-mass companions possibly biasing the centroid estimate. The axis ratios of the light and mass distributions are only weakly correlated (b). The position angles align very well within \u00b112\u00b0 for 8 out of the 12 systems (c). Systems with large misalignment have larger values of external shear (d). However, there is very weak to no correlation between the position angle misalignment and mass ellipticity (e).\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129897367/sty3397fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129897367\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/4/10.1093_mnras_sty3397/2/sty3397fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465403&Signature=OgPKZ5E7wNwWXm6vHLg395TJm6aYZP4LsQ7t9EcMJsk3icyzwXH85I3L6avtNd9l~JVWaA1w8x-ikBizDU1VUg7v-4mOmGmlJho5lb-iv9cRPKw4OlgDBM8qpDYbpAf~Va01jUKR8OvGIozLa3ZA4bqoRQrFUkBr405BshGTIklKPm2v~xxTBZ5yV0xuiTLaZbCEvdcTktCQ2tBpiO~5EjdBmQBkLKAIt7i1hud7zfKrtgTRaixeie9t6C9GcLxpFsCtfwW6vUFGGNC-O-wPr8DpQZyXd4BL0AC8M8B3VKGvif~eE~h-wHwqQwVxeSpeq2p2Obq0VttSXHUENY8~yg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129897367&ar=5251838&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Mass and light alignments in the deflector galaxies: comparison between (a) the mass and light centroids, (b) the axis ratios of the light and mass profiles, (c) the misalignment angle (between the mass and light profiles\u2019 position angles), (d) the misalignment angle and the external shear, and (e) the misalignment angle and the mass profile axial ratio. The thin-solid-grey lines attached to the data points show 1\u03c3 statistical uncertainty and the thick-solid-black bars annotated with \u2018sys.\u2019 in each figure shows the 1\u03c3 systematic uncertainty. The systematic uncertainty is estimated by marginalizing over various numerical settings for the system SDSS J0248+1913 as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>. In (a) the solid-grey ellipse centred at (0, 0) shows the root-mean-square (rms) spread of \u0394RA and \u0394Dec. for nine lens systems excluding the systems with large deviations: PS J0147+4630, DES J0408\u22125354, and PS J0630\u22121201. This rms spread can be taken as the upper limit of the systematics. The dashed grey line traces the perfect 1-to-1 correlation in (b) and the zero misalignment in (c) to aid visualisation. The centres of the mass and light distributions match very well (a). The systems with large offsets between the mass and light centroids have satellites or comparable-mass companions possibly biasing the centroid estimate. The axis ratios of the light and mass distributions are only weakly correlated (b). The position angles align very well within \u00b112\u00b0 for 8 out of the 12 systems (c). Systems with large misalignment have larger values of external shear (d). However, there is very weak to no correlation between the position angle misalignment and mass ellipticity (e).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/4/10.1093_mnras_sty3397/2/m_sty3397fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465403&amp;Signature=cI1qucA9-NDgMtJQ1-oANDUw987eZLksp3k7YunvUQ6Dvm~BLh8R4KEDE80R~7tuCLLsO8PAXCDgjS1sJJ7TqTy3AhyGzc84VKAmmdjeKIdS21tLDn7O7-gZq5USx~ZldCZSSwm5jnUDfg5W87BKdb7yEQN42X3ULfdI0XG7vT~PtlDYHkZZmtEESFhE3UIA9oimA-oHlX046VXkuUEB2brp4VKKT7aEr6Za2O4Y6rSpe9o-4duPHjgcF5lFQL4jkrbScky0tlg~oYbKbg1fZdGr9WwaoshRaPVeViStnW4PjbW79aKVwGBLRJdUPQdzTWd3fAtbkXikNfD2a-QF9g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Mass and light alignments in the deflector galaxies: comparison between (a) the mass and light centroids, (b) the axis ratios of the light and mass profiles, (c) the misalignment angle (between the mass and light profiles\u2019 position angles), (d) the misalignment angle and the external shear, and (e) the misalignment angle and the mass profile axial ratio. The thin-solid-grey lines attached to the data points show 1\u03c3 statistical uncertainty and the thick-solid-black bars annotated with \u2018sys.\u2019 in each figure shows the 1\u03c3 systematic uncertainty. The systematic uncertainty is estimated by marginalizing over various numerical settings for the system SDSS J0248+1913 as described in Section\u00a03.4. In (a) the solid-grey ellipse centred at (0, 0) shows the root-mean-square (rms) spread of \u0394RA and \u0394Dec. for nine lens systems excluding the systems with large deviations: PS J0147+4630, DES J0408\u22125354, and PS J0630\u22121201. This rms spread can be taken as the upper limit of the systematics. The dashed grey line traces the perfect 1-to-1 correlation in (b) and the zero misalignment in (c) to aid visualisation. The centres of the mass and light distributions match very well (a). The systems with large offsets between the mass and light centroids have satellites or comparable-mass companions possibly biasing the centroid estimate. The axis ratios of the light and mass distributions are only weakly correlated (b). The position angles align very well within \u00b112\u00b0 for 8 out of the 12 systems (c). Systems with large misalignment have larger values of external shear (d). However, there is very weak to no correlation between the position angle misalignment and mass ellipticity (e).\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129897367/sty3397fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129897367\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/4/10.1093_mnras_sty3397/2/sty3397fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465403&Signature=OgPKZ5E7wNwWXm6vHLg395TJm6aYZP4LsQ7t9EcMJsk3icyzwXH85I3L6avtNd9l~JVWaA1w8x-ikBizDU1VUg7v-4mOmGmlJho5lb-iv9cRPKw4OlgDBM8qpDYbpAf~Va01jUKR8OvGIozLa3ZA4bqoRQrFUkBr405BshGTIklKPm2v~xxTBZ5yV0xuiTLaZbCEvdcTktCQ2tBpiO~5EjdBmQBkLKAIt7i1hud7zfKrtgTRaixeie9t6C9GcLxpFsCtfwW6vUFGGNC-O-wPr8DpQZyXd4BL0AC8M8B3VKGvif~eE~h-wHwqQwVxeSpeq2p2Obq0VttSXHUENY8~yg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129897367&ar=5251838&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Mass and light alignments in the deflector galaxies: comparison between (a) the mass and light centroids, (b) the axis ratios of the light and mass profiles, (c) the misalignment angle (between the mass and light profiles\u2019 position angles), (d) the misalignment angle and the external shear, and (e) the misalignment angle and the mass profile axial ratio. The thin-solid-grey lines attached to the data points show 1\u03c3 statistical uncertainty and the thick-solid-black bars annotated with \u2018sys.\u2019 in each figure shows the 1\u03c3 systematic uncertainty. The systematic uncertainty is estimated by marginalizing over various numerical settings for the system SDSS J0248+1913 as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>. In (a) the solid-grey ellipse centred at (0, 0) shows the root-mean-square (rms) spread of \u0394RA and \u0394Dec. for nine lens systems excluding the systems with large deviations: PS J0147+4630, DES J0408\u22125354, and PS J0630\u22121201. This rms spread can be taken as the upper limit of the systematics. The dashed grey line traces the perfect 1-to-1 correlation in (b) and the zero misalignment in (c) to aid visualisation. The centres of the mass and light distributions match very well (a). The systems with large offsets between the mass and light centroids have satellites or comparable-mass companions possibly biasing the centroid estimate. The axis ratios of the light and mass distributions are only weakly correlated (b). The position angles align very well within \u00b112\u00b0 for 8 out of the 12 systems (c). Systems with large misalignment have larger values of external shear (d). However, there is very weak to no correlation between the position angle misalignment and mass ellipticity (e).</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129897368 id=\"129897368\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3-1>4.3.1 Centroid</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The centres of the mass and light distributions match very well for most of the quads with a root-mean-square (rms) of 0.04 excluding three outliers (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5a</a>). The three outliers are PS J0147+4630, DES J0408-5354, and PS J0630\u22121201. In PS J0630\u22121201, there are two deflectors with comparable mass creating a total of five images. If the two deflectors are embedded in the same dark matter halo, the centre of the luminous part of the deflector can have an offset from the centre of the halo mass. The other two outliers also have nearby companions possibly biasing the centroid estimation.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129897370 id=\"129897370\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3-2>4.3.2 Ellipticity</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We find a weak correlation between the ellipticity parameters of the mass and light distribution for the whole sample (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5b</a>). We calculate the Pearson correlation coefficient between the axis ratios <em>q</em> and <em>q</em><sub>L</sub> of the mass and light distributions, respectively, in the following way. We sample 1000 points from a two-dimensional Gaussian distribution that is centred on the axial ratio pair (<em>q, q</em><sub>L</sub>) for each quad. We take the standard deviation for this Gaussian distribution along each axis equal to the 1\u03c3 systematic+statistical uncertainty. We take the covariance between the sampled points for each lens as zero as we observe no degeneracy in the posterior PDF of the axis ratios for individual lenses. The Pearson correlation coefficient for the distribution of the sampled points from all the quads is <em>r</em> = 0.2 (weak correlation).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129897372 id=\"129897372\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3-3>4.3.3 Position angle</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The position angles of the elliptical mass and light distributions are well aligned for 9 out of 13 quads. The standard deviation of the misalignment in position angles for these eight lenses is 11\u00b0 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5c</a>). The systems with large misalignment also have large external shear. We find a strong correlation between the misalignment angle and the external shear magnitude (<em>r</em> = 0.74, Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5d</a>). We find weak correlation between the misalignment angle and the mass axial ratio <em>q</em> (<em>r</em> = 0.21, Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5e</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=129897374 id=\"129897374\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-4>4.4 Deviation of flux ratios from macro-model</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Stars or dark subhaloes in the deflector can produce additional magnification or de-magnification of the quasar images through microlensing and millilensing, respectively (for detailed description, see Schneider, Kochanek &amp; Wambsganss <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib111\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib111\" data-open=\"bib111\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). In that case, the flux ratios of the quasar images will be different than those predicted by the smooth macro-model. Deviation of the flux ratios can also be produced by baryonic structures (Gilman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) or discs (Hsueh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), quasar variability with a time delay, and dust extinction (Yonehara, Hirashita &amp; Richter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib143\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib143\" data-open=\"bib143\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Anguita et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). We quantify this deviation of the flux ratios in the quasar images as a \u03c7<sup>2</sup>-value by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ4\" content-id=\"equ4\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\chi ^2_{f} = \\sum _{{\\rm I, J} \\in \\lbrace {\\rm A,\\ B,\\ C,\\ D} \\rbrace }^{{\\rm I} \\ne {\\rm J}} \\frac{\\left(f_{\\rm IJ,\\ observed} - f_{\\rm IJ,\\ model}\\right)^2}{\\sigma _{f_{\\rm IJ}}^2},\r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(4)</span></div>where <em>f</em><sub>IJ</sub> = <em>F</em><sub>I</sub>/<em>F</em><sub>J</sub> is the flux ratio between the images I and J. We assume 20 per cent flux error giving <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _{f_{\\rm IJ}} = 0.28 f_{\\rm IJ}$|\u2060</span>. We set this error level considering the typical order of magnitude for intrinsic variability of quasars (e.g. Bonvin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Courbin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Although, many of the quads in our sample have short predicted time-delays (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblC1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblC1\" data-open=\"tblC1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">C1</a>), where intrinsic variability is not a major source of deviation in flux-ratios, we take 20 per cent as a conservative error estimate for these lenses.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">If the flux ratios are consistent with the macro-model, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi ^2_f$|</span> is expected to follow the \u03c7<sup>2</sup>(3) distribution, i.e. <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi ^2_f \\sim \\chi ^2(3)$|\u2060</span>, as only three out of the six flux ratios are independent producing three degrees of freedom. However, the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi ^2_f$|</span>-distribution is shifted toward a higher value than \u03c7<sup>2</sup>(3) (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). The mean of the combined distribution of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log _{10}{\\chi ^2_f}$|</span> from all the three <em>HST</em> bands is 2.04. A Kolmogorov\u2013Smirnov test of whether the observed <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi ^2_f$|</span>-distribution matches with the \u03c7<sup>2</sup>(3)-distribution yields a <em>p</em>-value of \u223c0. The shift is higher in shorter wavelengths. The mean of the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log _{10}\\chi _f^2$|</span>\u2019s in the F160W, F814W, and F475X bands are 1.85, 2.09, and 2.17, respectively. This is expected, as the quasar size is smaller in shorter wavelengths making it more affected by microlensing, and as shorter wavelengths are also more affected by dust extinction.</p>                        <a id=\"129897377\" scrollto-destination=\"129897377\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/4/10.1093_mnras_sty3397/2/m_sty3397fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465403&amp;Signature=P2jizh7bX1YJupSmiBZJBir48ewvIw79nGAdaVipk5LHznq-twsDkpKWRNXhXBA5HkiWuu6ythqv1R6C6kxc4~sr6hn2~J8-XD0ffq8ikvoPPfxeq-cLc5wky7e6SWAgNTxs0zXzBZOWi45nQ1RASAefH7diW1IHYkVw50v2nB0DdcI~-5Ru-XPLtji7GZZY4vq0-08WVA~pZzdvrnEutglKBgnCVqwSXQkQc6iS21ecd8COAfnZZm48CApU~VOwVvd8mwOp~AYZbzIetzJiKuYPX3HRF6wOureCdWjlUeZeHxnOmS9ZF5jyAVLRKj3pLJkuNPAPybDKiB1EexMKdQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of $\\chi ^2_f$ for flux-ratio anomalies from Equation\u00a0(4) assuming 20 per cent error in flux. The distribution is for 12 quads in our sample excluding PS J0630\u22121201. The $\\chi ^2_f$-distributions in bands F160W, F814W, and F475X are shown in orange, green, and purple shaded regions, respectively. The $\\chi ^2_f$-distribution from all the bands combined is shown as the grey shaded region. The black dashed line shows the expected $\\chi ^2_f \\sim \\chi ^2(3)$ distribution in the absence of microlensing. The arrows on the top show the mean of the $\\chi _f^2$-values in bands F160W (solid orange), F814W (dashed green), and F475X (dotted purple). The combined $\\chi ^2_f$-distribution is shifted to higher values. The shift is higher for shorter wavelengths, as the quasar size gets smaller with decreasing wavelength making it more susceptible to microlensing.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129897377/sty3397fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129897377\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/4/10.1093_mnras_sty3397/2/sty3397fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465403&Signature=H-8YEcoBifoVmwkRmNZHAj0E-RfW3qVtFFP0JbAmfl9V7gHDj4b30AR9~4n5t2N02fepF3x4tl9NUhNS5rTpnzC7-6~nzuWE8a3ltM5oLPJzCBILwKabBBa-Sb7KxEukYyvsM3mHNB~sCn8at86a9t8WQ2mqiR9va9Onmni8A5a07cRzvx39L6xQw0oa7HVUMTjrMEXmvQm5Fd-oqYHNdUefvuvdsmmAJdpEmHTcLN-Y~Rt8OlnPLi~3Eh5L~gc6EHhOB8UBSu-F9KwT0aGCQBveRomjbhep8-4z4Rx4-9Ajg7A~EjTDd0QVRnLkEfE8Mk9YBUhLqo5lw-D7WptURA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129897377&ar=5251838&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi ^2_f$|</span> for flux-ratio anomalies from Equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ4\"></span><a href=\"#equ4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>) assuming 20 per cent error in flux. The distribution is for 12 quads in our sample excluding PS J0630\u22121201. The <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi ^2_f$|</span>-distributions in bands F160W, F814W, and F475X are shown in orange, green, and purple shaded regions, respectively. The <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi ^2_f$|</span>-distribution from all the bands combined is shown as the grey shaded region. The black dashed line shows the expected <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi ^2_f \\sim \\chi ^2(3)$|</span> distribution in the absence of microlensing. The arrows on the top show the mean of the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi _f^2$|</span>-values in bands F160W (solid orange), F814W (dashed green), and F475X (dotted purple). The combined <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi ^2_f$|</span>-distribution is shifted to higher values. The shift is higher for shorter wavelengths, as the quasar size gets smaller with decreasing wavelength making it more susceptible to microlensing.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/4/10.1093_mnras_sty3397/2/m_sty3397fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465403&amp;Signature=P2jizh7bX1YJupSmiBZJBir48ewvIw79nGAdaVipk5LHznq-twsDkpKWRNXhXBA5HkiWuu6ythqv1R6C6kxc4~sr6hn2~J8-XD0ffq8ikvoPPfxeq-cLc5wky7e6SWAgNTxs0zXzBZOWi45nQ1RASAefH7diW1IHYkVw50v2nB0DdcI~-5Ru-XPLtji7GZZY4vq0-08WVA~pZzdvrnEutglKBgnCVqwSXQkQc6iS21ecd8COAfnZZm48CApU~VOwVvd8mwOp~AYZbzIetzJiKuYPX3HRF6wOureCdWjlUeZeHxnOmS9ZF5jyAVLRKj3pLJkuNPAPybDKiB1EexMKdQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of $\\chi ^2_f$ for flux-ratio anomalies from Equation\u00a0(4) assuming 20 per cent error in flux. The distribution is for 12 quads in our sample excluding PS J0630\u22121201. The $\\chi ^2_f$-distributions in bands F160W, F814W, and F475X are shown in orange, green, and purple shaded regions, respectively. The $\\chi ^2_f$-distribution from all the bands combined is shown as the grey shaded region. The black dashed line shows the expected $\\chi ^2_f \\sim \\chi ^2(3)$ distribution in the absence of microlensing. The arrows on the top show the mean of the $\\chi _f^2$-values in bands F160W (solid orange), F814W (dashed green), and F475X (dotted purple). The combined $\\chi ^2_f$-distribution is shifted to higher values. The shift is higher for shorter wavelengths, as the quasar size gets smaller with decreasing wavelength making it more susceptible to microlensing.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129897377/sty3397fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129897377\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/4/10.1093_mnras_sty3397/2/sty3397fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465403&Signature=H-8YEcoBifoVmwkRmNZHAj0E-RfW3qVtFFP0JbAmfl9V7gHDj4b30AR9~4n5t2N02fepF3x4tl9NUhNS5rTpnzC7-6~nzuWE8a3ltM5oLPJzCBILwKabBBa-Sb7KxEukYyvsM3mHNB~sCn8at86a9t8WQ2mqiR9va9Onmni8A5a07cRzvx39L6xQw0oa7HVUMTjrMEXmvQm5Fd-oqYHNdUefvuvdsmmAJdpEmHTcLN-Y~Rt8OlnPLi~3Eh5L~gc6EHhOB8UBSu-F9KwT0aGCQBveRomjbhep8-4z4Rx4-9Ajg7A~EjTDd0QVRnLkEfE8Mk9YBUhLqo5lw-D7WptURA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129897377&ar=5251838&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi ^2_f$|</span> for flux-ratio anomalies from Equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ4\"></span><a href=\"#equ4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>) assuming 20 per cent error in flux. The distribution is for 12 quads in our sample excluding PS J0630\u22121201. The <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi ^2_f$|</span>-distributions in bands F160W, F814W, and F475X are shown in orange, green, and purple shaded regions, respectively. The <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi ^2_f$|</span>-distribution from all the bands combined is shown as the grey shaded region. The black dashed line shows the expected <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi ^2_f \\sim \\chi ^2(3)$|</span> distribution in the absence of microlensing. The arrows on the top show the mean of the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi _f^2$|</span>-values in bands F160W (solid orange), F814W (dashed green), and F475X (dotted purple). The combined <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi ^2_f$|</span>-distribution is shifted to higher values. The shift is higher for shorter wavelengths, as the quasar size gets smaller with decreasing wavelength making it more susceptible to microlensing.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=129897378 id=\"129897378\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 SUMMARY AND DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We presented a general framework to uniformly model large samples of quads while attempting to minimize investigator time. We apply this framework to model a sample of 13 quads and simultaneously fit imaging data from three <em>HST</em> WFC3 bands. All the quads are satisfactorily (<em>p</em>-value <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\gtrsim 10^{-8}$|\u2060</span>) modelled in our uniform framework. We choose the <em>p</em>-value threshold to be suitably low to be applicable to our quad sample with large morphological variation while being able to point out deficiencies in the modelling choice of profiles along the decision tree. In the end, most of the lens systems in our sample are modelled with <em>p</em>-value \u223c 1 (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). Thus, we showed that a large variety of quads can be modelled with a basic set of mass and light profiles under our framework, i.e. all the quads in our sample are \u2018happy\u2019 (or, at least \u2018content\u2019).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Only one of the quads in our sample, DES J0408\u22125354, has measured time delays: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta t_{\\rm AB}^{\\rm observed} = -112 \\pm 2.1$|</span> d, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta t_{\\rm AD}^{\\rm observed} = -155.5 \\pm 12.8$|</span> d (Courbin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). The predicted time delays <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta t_{\\rm AB}^{\\rm predicted} = -100 \\pm 9$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta t_{\\rm AD}^{\\rm predicted} = -140 \\pm 13$|</span> d (Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec8\">C</a>) are in good agreement with the measured values, although the measured values were not used as constraints in the modelling procedure.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to make the problem computationally tractable for much larger samples, we made some simplifying assumptions. Thus, whereas some of the lensing quantities, such as Einstein radius, deflector centre of mass, position angle and ellipticity, and image flux ratios, are robustly determined, our models are not appropriate for all applications. In particular, science cases requiring high precision might require more sophisticated modelling for each individual lens system.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The main simplifying assumptions in our work are (1) we restricted our models to simple yet general profiles to describe the mass and light distributions and (2) we assume no colour gradient in the deflector and source fluxes. Thus, we use the same scalelengths and ellipticity in the deflector- and source-light profiles in different bands while fitting simultaneously. Some straightforward ways to further improve the lens modelling are to allow for colour dependence of the light distribution of the source and deflector, explicitly including mass distribution of more nearby companions or satellites, increasing the number of shapelets (<em>n</em><sub>max\u2009</sub>), and consider composite mass models consisting of both stellar and dark matter components.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We illustrate the information content of this large sample of quads by investigating the alignment between the light and mass distributions in the deflector galaxies, and the distribution of so-called flux ratio anomalies. Our key results are as follows: <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The centres of the mass and light distributions match very well (the rms of the offsets is 0.04).</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">We find the correlation between the ellipticity of the mass and light distributions to be weak (Pearson correlation coefficient, <em>r</em> = 0.2).</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The position angles of the major axes of the mass and light distributions are well-aligned within \u00b111\u00b0 for 9 out of 13 lenses.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Systems with high (&gt;30\u00b0) misalignment angle between the light and mass also have large external shear (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\gamma _{\\rm ext} \\gtrsim 0.1$|\u2060</span>). The Pearson correlation coefficient between the misalignment angle and the external shear is <em>r</em> = 0.74.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The measured flux ratios between the images depart significantly from those predicted by our simple mass models. These flux ratio anomalies are strongest in the bluest band, consistent with microlensing being the main physical driver, in addition to millilensing associated with unseen satellites.</p></li></ul></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our finding of weak correlation between the light and mass ellipticity slightly agrees with Keeton et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>), Ferreras et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>) and Rusu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib106\" data-open=\"bib106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) who find no correlation. However, we do not find a strong correlation as Sluse et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib116\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib116\" data-open=\"bib116\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) and Gavazzi et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) report. The weak correlation between the mass and light ellipticity in our study is consistent with the hierarchical formation scenario of elliptical galaxies, where the remnants in the simulation of multiple mergers are shown to have no correlation between the halo and light ellipticity (Weil &amp; Hernquist <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib136\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib136\" data-open=\"bib136\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>). Moreover, some of the deflectors in our sample are discy galaxies. The projected ellipticity of discy galaxies will not be correlated with the halo ellipticity if viewed from arbitrary orientations.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Moreover, dark matter haloes are expected to be rounder than the stellar distribution from simulation (Dubinski &amp; Carlberg <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1991</a>; Warren et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib135\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib135\" data-open=\"bib135\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>; Dubinski <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1994</a>) with reported agreements to observations (Bruderer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Rusu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib106\" data-open=\"bib106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). In our sample, the majority of the systems follow this prediction. Only three systems have significantly flatter mass distribution than the light distribution (DES J0408\u22125354, PS J0630\u22121201, and WISE J2344\u22123056). All these systems have satellites or comparable-mass companions and thus are not the typically relaxed systems where we expect this to hold. In contrast, four systems in our sample are significantly rounder in mass than in light: ATLAS J0259\u22121635, DES J0405\u22123308, DES J0420\u22124037, and PS J1606\u22122333. These are likely to be discy galaxies from visual inspection of their shapes. This explains the large difference in ellipticity between the mass and light.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To reliably compare the ellipticity of the light and mass distribution, the ellipticity needs to be estimated within the same aperture, or within an aperture large enough beyond that the ellipticity does not significantly evolve. From a strong-lens system, only the total (projected) mass within the Einstein radius can be estimated. If the Einstein radius is much smaller than the effective radius of the deflector galaxy, the comparison of ellipticity between light and mass may not be representative of the entire galaxy.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We find a strong alignment between the mass and light position angles, which agree very well with previous reports (Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Ferreras et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib127\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib127\" data-open=\"bib127\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Sluse et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib116\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib116\" data-open=\"bib116\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Bruderer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Our result is also in agreement with Bruderer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) that the systems with high misalignment (&gt;30\u00b0) also have strong external shear (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\gamma _{\\rm ext} \\gtrsim 0.1$|\u2060</span>). The absence of systems with high misalignment but low external shear is in agreement with the prediction of galaxy formation models. Orbits that are highly misaligned in isolated galaxies (thus with low external shear) are shown to be rare and unstable (Heiligman &amp; Schwarzschild <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1979</a>; Martinet &amp; de Zeeuw <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>; Adams et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Debattista et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). The misalignment in isolated galaxies can only be sustained by a constant gas-inflow in blue starburst galaxies (Debattista et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Furthermore, for systems with \u03b8<sub>E</sub>/\u03b8<sub>eff</sub> &lt; 1, the lensing mass is likely to be dominated by the stellar mass. In that case, relatively stronger correlation between the mass and the light distributions is naturally expected. A comparison between the dark matter and luminous matter distribution would be more interesting in regard to directly testing \u039bCDM and galaxy formation theories. However, broadly speaking, large deviations in ellipticity and alignment in our sample have to be explained by the presence of dark matter. However, direct comparison between the dark and luminous mass distributions requires composite mass models with dark and luminous components as adopted by Bruderer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Gomer &amp; Williams (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) find that two elliptical mass distributions corresponding to the dark matter and baryon with an offset can better reproduce the image positions in quads than just one smooth elliptical mass distribution with external shear. Those kinds of mass models are beyond the scope of this paper and left for future studies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The departures of flux-ratios from the smooth model in the discy galaxies in our sample are not at the extreme of the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi _f^2$|</span>-distribution. This further supports microlensing by foreground stars being the dominant source of the flux-ratio anomaly.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Detailed follow-up of this sample is under way, to measure redshift and velocity dispersion of the deflectors as well as the time delays between the quasars and the properties of the environment. Once follow-up is completed, we will use this sample to address fundamental questions such as the determination of the Hubble Constant (e.g. Bonvin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), the nature of dark matter (e.g. Gilman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), and the normalization of the stellar IMF in massive galaxies (e.g. Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib108\" data-open=\"bib108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=129897391 id=\"129897391\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" >ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">AJS, SB, TT, and CDF acknowledge support by National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) through Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI) grant <em>HST</em>-GO-15320, and by the Packard Foundation through a Packard Fellowship to TT. class=\"backfootnotegroup-title\" >Footnotes</h2>\r\n<div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://strides.astro.ucla.edu\" target=\"_blank\">http://strides.astro.ucla.edu</a>.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">2</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri utilized the Hoffman2 Shared Cluster provided by UCLA Institute for Digital Research and Education\u2019s Research Technology Group. <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://idre.ucla.edu/hoffman2\" target=\"_blank\">https://idre.ucla.edu/hoffman2</a>.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn4\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/129897409\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=129897410 id=\"129897410\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>APPENDIX B: CONVERGENCE, SHEAR, AND STELLAR CONVERGENCE</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The convergence \u03ba, shear \u03b3, and the stellar convergence \u03ba<sub>\u22c6</sub> at the image positions for each lens are given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblB1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblB1\" data-open=\"tblB1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">B1</a>. The convergence at the image position is given by the lens mass distribution. We assume a constant mass-to-light ratio to convert the surface brightness distribution into a stellar surface mass-density distribution. We choose the maximum normalization factor for the stellar convergence that meets these two criteria: (i) the stellar convergence is smaller than the convergence and (ii) the integrated stellar convergence is smaller than two-thirds of the integrated convergence within half of the effective radius (Auger et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010b</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"129897412\" scrollto-destination=\"129897412\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tblB1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tblB1\" data-id=\"tblB1\"><span class=\"label\">Table B1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Convergence, shear, and stellar convergence at the image positions. The reported uncertainties are systematic and statistical uncertainties added in quadrature. The stellar convergence, \u03ba<sub>\u22c6</sub>, is estimated from the F160W band for the lenses with double S\u00e9rsic fit for the lens light.</p></div> </div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/129897412\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=129897413 id=\"129897413\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec8>APPENDIX C: TIME DELAYS</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The time delay between two images I and J is given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equC1\" content-id=\"equC1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\Delta t_{\\rm IJ} = \\frac{D_{\\Delta t}}{c} \\left[ \\frac{1}{2} (\\boldsymbol {\\theta }_{\\rm I} - \\boldsymbol {\\beta })^2 - \\frac{1}{2} (\\boldsymbol {\\theta }_{\\rm J} - \\boldsymbol {\\beta })^2 - \\psi (\\boldsymbol {\\theta _{\\rm I}}) + \\psi (\\boldsymbol {\\theta }_{\\rm J}) \\right],\r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(C1)</span></div>where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol {\\theta }$|</span> is the image position, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol {\\beta }$|</span> is the source position, \u03c8 is the lensing potential, <em>c</em> is the speed of light, and <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> is the time-delay distance given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equC2\" content-id=\"equC2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nD_{\\Delta t} = \\left(1 + z_{\\rm d}\\right) \\frac{D_{\\rm d} D_{\\rm s}}{D_{\\rm ds}}.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(C2)</span></div>Here, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>d</sub> is the deflector redshift, <em>D</em><sub>d</sub>, <em>D</em><sub>s</sub>, and <em>D</em><sub>ds</sub> are the angular diameter distances between the observer and the deflector, between the observer and the source, and between the deflector and the source, respectively. The predicted time delays between the images for the quads are given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblC1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblC1\" data-open=\"tblC1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">C1</a>.</div>                        <a id=\"129897415\" scrollto-destination=\"129897415\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tblC1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tblC1\" data-id=\"tblC1\"><span class=\"label\">Table C1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Predicted time-delays between the quasar images. The reported uncertainties are systematic and statistical uncertainties added in quadrature. We adopt fiducial redshifts <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>d</sub> = 0.5 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>s</sub> = 2, where the redshifts are not measured yet.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>System name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>d</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>s</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394<em>t</em><sub>AC</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394<em>t</em><sub>AD</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(d)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(d)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(d)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>PS J0147+4630\u00a0</td><td>0.572\u00a0</td><td>2.341\u00a0</td><td>\u22122.1\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3\u00a0</td><td>\u22127\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>\u2212193\u00a0\u00b1\u00a018\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=129897416 id=\"129897416\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec9>APPENDIX D: LENS MODELS</h3>\r\n<p The fourth row shows the reconstructed source in the F160W band, the convergence, and the magnification model.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397figd3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129897420/sty3397figd3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397figd3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129897420\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/4/10.1093_mnras_sty3397/2/sty3397figd3.jpeg?Expires=1611465403&Signature=HHkRopY6ue8v2kSMR8JipyqIMBRXmCQUKFObuXyp-v~ubSFcQ-EvZ23Ybu53AEg3A-oBDGp6fBZOag7I7g4fqXy1vjZmHDg2O14VxlFsgTMhzqOgoynr-i7pmqHK2N9b6~n9Uf1XBo4M9EMcaJRsBFWpQlbYeEFzccJFO5jKXU39WPfX2kmaNxwS66Dp9XzZWlDyjxVie9zptD6g7UBqfw-q7QIgm20DZmJIXS6ZjBFn4pxGUrRB5FPqGHYChMCL53io7A1YVQZlks3HrvWnzU6~s5JGocbuO2BaSaFpaAnnjwv5UHIYUudv8iqdnGjAQHIrKLpNGdbTP0pX4js8PA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129897420&ar=5251838&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3397figd3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Best-fitting models for WISE J2344\u22123056. The first three rows show the observed image, reconstructed lens image, and the normalized residuals in three <em>HST</em> bands: F160W, F814W, and F475X, respectively. The fourth row shows the reconstructed source in the F160W band, the convergence, and the magnification model.</p></div></div>        <!-- /foreach -->\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"article-metadata-standalone-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n\r\n        \r\n                    <h2 class=\"authorNotes-section-title\" id=\"authorNotesSectionTitle\" scrollto-destination=\"authorNotesSectionTitle\">Author notes</h2>\r\n<div content-id=\"req-154203375939228345\"><span class=\"fn\"><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Packard Fellow.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"req-154203375939225700\"><span class=\"fn\"><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Subaru Fellow.</p></div></span></div><div class=\"copyright copyright-statement\">\u00a9 2018 The Author(s) Published by Oxford University Press on behalf of the Royal Jos\u00e9 Cristino 77, Rio de Janeiro, RJ-20921-400, Brazil; Observat\u00f3rio Nacional, Rua Gal. Green Street, Urbana, IL 61801, USA; National Center for Supercomputing Applications, 1205 West Clark Str, Urbana, IL 61801, USA), CJ(Instituci\u00f3 Catalana de Recerca i Estudis Avan\u00e7ats, E-08010 Barcelona, Spain), CK(Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, 4800 Oak Grove Dr., Pasadena, CA 91109, USA), CL(Centro de Investigaciones Energ\u00e9ticas, Medioambientales y Tecnol\u00f3gicas (CIEMAT), Madrid, Spain), CM(Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, PO Box 500, Batavia, IL 60510, USA), CN(Centro de Investigaciones Energ\u00e9ticas, Medioambientales y Tecnol\u00f3gicas (CIEMAT), Madrid, Spain), CO(School of Physics and Astronomy, University of Southampton, Southampton SO17 1BJ, UK), CP(Brandeis University, Physics Department, 415 South Street, Waltham, MA 02453, USA), CQ(Department of Physics &amp; Astronomy, University College London, Gower Street, London WC1E 6BT, UK; Instituto de F\u00edsica Gleb Wataghin, Universidade Estadual de Campinas, 13083-859, Campinas, SP, Brazil), CR(Computer Science and Mathematics Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN 37831, USA), CS(National Center for Supercomputing Applications, 1205 West Clark Str, Urbana, IL 61801, USA), CT(Department of Physics, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, USA), CU(Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory, National Optical Astronomy Observatory, Casilla 603, La Serena, Chile)"], "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "volume": "483", "publication_year": "2019/03/1", "start_page": "5649", "end_page": "5671", "keywords": ["gravitational lensing: strong", "methods: data analysis", "galaxies: elliptical and lenticular", "cD", "galaxies: structure", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2019MNRAS.483.5649S", "abstract": "Strong-gravitational lens systems with quadruply imaged quasars (quads) are unique probes to address several fundamental problems in cosmology and astrophysics. Although they are intrinsically very rare, ongoing and planned wide-field deep-sky surveys are set to discover thousands of such systems in the next decade. It is thus paramount to devise a general framework to model strong-lens systems to cope with this large influx without being limited by expert investigator time. We propose such a general modelling framework (implemented with the publicly available software LENSTRONOMY) and apply it to uniformly model three-band Hubble Space Telescope Wide Field Camera 3 images of 13 quads. This is the largest uniformly modelled sample of quads to date and paves the way for a variety of studies. To illustrate the scientific content of the sample, we investigate the alignment between the mass and light distribution in the deflectors. The position angles of these distributions are well-aligned, except when there is strong external shear. However, we find no correlation between the ellipticity of the light and mass distributions. We also show that the observed flux-ratios between the images depart significantly from the predictions of simple smooth models. The departures are strongest in the bluest band, consistent with microlensing being the dominant cause in addition to millilensing. Future papers will exploit this rich data set in combination with ground-based spectroscopy and time delays to determine quantities such as the Hubble constant, the free streaming length of dark matter, and the normalization of the initial stellar mass function.", "doi": "10.1093/mnras/sty3397", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1807.09278", "issn": "0035-8711", "number": "4"}, "Inspection status": "Incomplete"}
